subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Digital Voice Recorder Advice
author: Ursula Bielski
full_text:
--0-419788003-1198947086=:69098
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Oops.  I forgot to answer: No, I have not given up ghost hunting at all, but over the years I have come to focus more on the collection and distribution of experiences than on encountering phenomena myself.  ITC has really affirmed this for me.
  I've felt all along that my job is to make people aware that spiritual phenomena go on all the time in millions of lives; I'm not a scientist and I know nothing I do will change the way science thinks.  BUT if I can open the minds of young people today, perhaps our future scientists will make it their business to figure all this out.  
  I know this is a lot of what ITC experimenters are doing: convincing others of the afterlife by their recorded evidence.  Amazing things can happen when THAT happens.  
  Again, Mark Macy is so wonderful because he has dedicated his life to this.  He and his colleagues have received such detailed descriptions of how the afterlife works, that they have helped the living change their lives to erase the fear of death--and to live in a way that brings us to as high a spiritual level as possible right away when our bodies die.  This means, for example, dealing with issues and addictions, that plague us in life, since the spirits tell us we take it all with us!  That is, death isn't a cure-all.
  Any glimpse at the history of ITC shows us that all of this has been gradually growing since the 19th century, when state-of-the-art graphite pencils and telegraphs were used to contact the dead.  Since then, there have been "breakthroughs" a number of times when astounding floods of messages have come through.
  You experimenters are all so incredible--I'm amazed every day at your love, dedication and faith.  Surely something wonderful is going to come from all this, and I think it's going to come during our lifetimes.
   
  Ursula
   
   
  
Robin Searcy Henson <MudPuddleFarm@...> wrote:
              Hello Bill,
   
  Yes, I did steal that phrase from Ursula because I thought it described what I was doing as compared to what I would like to be doing!
   
  I like what you said about focus on the equipment helping to establish the psychic connection.  It makes so much sense.  This discussion has definitely shown me that mental tools and preparation are as important as physical ones.  
   
  Thank you for your input.
   
  Robin
   
   
    ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: psi_research 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, December 28, 2007 9:37 PM
  Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: Digital Voice Recorder Advice
  

    oops. I see it was Ursula who posted the "r vs. r" statement. And
Ursula your post is so much more eloquent and you've articulated the
point much better than I could. I'll bow out of your way -Bill 

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "psi_research" <vilhellm@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Robin,
> Your phrase of "ritualized vs. random" is interesting. There are many
> who believe that communication is between the conscious of the
> researcher and the entity and the equipment is secondary. It's easy to
> get swept up in the technology and forget there is possibly a psychic
> connection going on. With that said, focusing on equipment actually
> can help the researcher become receptive to establishing a
> communication link. While paying attention to the equipment, we forget
> about the daily distractions and minor irritations that may prevent us
> from establishing contact. 
> 
> The setting up the gear we use could be considered the first part of
> the "ritual". I like to clear my mind, set up equipment, mess with it
> some more, then I am mentally prepare to begin what I hope will be a
> successful session.
> 
> I guess "random" recording to me would be what happens in the field
> during a paranormal investigation. I don't bring Box technology into a
> location with the intention of possibly contacting lingering spirits
> at that location but I do bring audio recorders in hopes of recording
> evp's.
> 
> I find the Box works perhaps even better when I'm in a familiar place
> like the room in my home that is designated for that purpose. I do
> desire to have the finest Box technology that is possible but more
> important is the association that seems to occur between the
> researcher and the Box that is favored. Despite some of the benefits
> of the new gear, the one that I seem to have a connection with is one
> that requires a little more finesse to operate. -Bill
> 
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "Robin Henson" <MudPuddleFarm@> wrote:
> >
> > Wow, thanks for your help guys!
> > 
> > Ursula, your post was lovely. I've been promising myself to learn 
> > more about Mark Macy's work and will check out his website ASAP. 
> > Ritualized versus random recording makes sense to me now, as I want 
> > to accomplish true communication rather than continue being verbally 
> > abused. Have you given up "ghost hunting" altogether? 
> > 
> > I've been looking at the Olympus VN-4100 PC, Zack! I don't know if I 
> > need that much recording time, but I sure have liked the one I have 
> > and wouldn't mind upgrading a bit. 
> > 
> > Hi Frank! I basically follow your suggestion when recording, and once 
> > I learned to be quiet I actually started getting responses. I think 
> > the entities at my house got tired of playing with me though, and now 
> > they aren't saying anything. I kind of miss them, but I do feel it's 
> > time to move on.
> > 
> > Robin 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Zack Widup <w9sz@> wrote:
> > >
> > > 
> > > Hi Robin,
> > > 
> > > Radio Shack now carries the Olympus VN-4100PC at about the same 
> > price I 
> > > paid for my VN-960PC a couple years ago. I've been very happy with 
> > the 
> > > 960. The 4100 has about 4 times the recording time, I think. That 
> > would 
> > > make it about 24 hours.
> > > 
> > > Zack
> > > 
> > > On Sat, 29 Dec 2007, Robin Henson wrote:
> > > 
> > > > Hi all,
> > > >
> > > > I'm new to the group but probably know some of you from another
> > > > list. I haven't been too active in the realm of EVP recording
> > > > recently, but have had what I consider excellent results in the 
> > past
> > > > using my little refurbished Ebay-bargain Olympus VN-120 PC.
> > > >
> > > > I'm anxious to start recording again and am feeling pretty
> > > > overwhelmed by the technology you all seem to be using. I know a
> > > > little about using good headphones and denoiser programs, but 
> > beyond
> > > > that I'm electronically challenged. Still, I wonder if there are
> > > > simple techniques I can experiment with to increase my success. I
> > > > think I'm a little bored.
> > > >
> > > > I've felt pretty strongly that I've been communicating with a very
> > > > small number of entities, and I'm wondering if that's due to the
> > > > limitations of my equipment. My most impressive EVPs have always 
> > been
> > > > captured around my own home, particularly outside on the hill and
> > > > near the barn. I've gotten two inside my house (after inviting
> > > > spirits in), and probably 75% in total have been negative 
> > messages.
> > > >
> > > > Anyway, I'm thinking about getting another DVR and would love to 
> > hear
> > > > your thoughts and recommendations about which ones are best. I 
> > would
> > > > like to communicate with more advanced entities eventually, but
> > > > unfortunately don't have the brain for building anything myself.
> > > >
> > > > Thanks!
> > > >
> > > > Robin
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Yahoo! Groups Links
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > >
> >
>
